sen.j: 後水尾天皇（ごみずのおてんのう、慶長元年6月4日（1596年6月29日） - 延宝8年8月19日（1680年9月11日） 在位：慶長16年3月27日（1611年5月9日） - 寛永6年11月8日（1629年12月22日）は第108代天皇である。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Mizunoo (June 29th, 1596 - September 11th, 1680), his reign was May 9th, 1611 - December 22nd, 1629, he was the 108th Emperor.
Emperor Go-Mizunoo (June 29, 1596 - September 11, 1680) was the 108th Emperor (his reign lasted from May 9, 1611 to December 22, 1629).
Emperor Gomizunoo (June 29, 1596 - September 11, 1680) was the 108th Emperor (his reign lasted from May 9, 1611 to December 22, 1629).

sen.j: 諱は政仁（ことひと）。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Kotohito.
His posthumous name was Kotohito.
His personal name was Kotohito.

sen.j: 後陽成天皇はかねてから豊臣秀吉の意向で立てられた儲君・第1皇子良仁親王（覚深法親王）を廃して、自らの手で次期天皇を決める事を望んでいた。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Yozei wished to get rid of Crown Prince, the first Prince, Prince Katahito (monk-Prince Kakushin), who was appointed by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's disposition, and wished to decide next successor to become Emperor.

Emperor Go-Yozei wanted to get rid of the crown prince (the first prince), Prince Katahito (the monk-prince Kakushin), who had been appointed according to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's disposition, and wanted to make his own decision as to who should be the next Emperor.

Emperor Goyozei wanted to get rid of the crown prince (the first prince), Imperial Prince Katahito (monk-Prince Kakushin), who had been appointed according to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's disposition, and wanted to make his own decision as to who should be the next Emperor.

sen.j: だが、関ヶ原の合戦によって新たに権力の座を手に入れた徳川家康もまた皇位継承に介入し、良仁親王の出家（皇位継承からの排除）は認めるものの、これに替わる次期天皇として嫡出男子であった第3皇子の政仁親王の擁立を求めた。
sen.e: However Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who took the political power after the Battle of Sekigahara got involved in the Imperial succession, although he accepted Prince Katahito to become a priest, (not being included in the Imperial succession) he demanded the third Prince, Prince Kotohito to enthrone for next Emperor, who was the legitimacy son.

However, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who had seized political power after the Battle of Sekigahara, got involved in the imperial succession, and although he accepted Prince Katahito's joining the priesthood (not being included in the imperial succession) he demanded that the third prince, Kotohito, be enthroned as the next Emperor, since he was the legitimate son.

However, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who had seized political power after the Battle of Sekigahara, got involved in the imperial succession, and although he accepted Imperial Prince Katahito's joining the priesthood (not being included in the imperial succession) he demanded that the third prince, Kotohito, be enthroned as the next Emperor, since he was the legitimate son.

sen.j: 最終的に後陽成天皇はこれを受け入れたものの、結果的には自己の希望に反して家康の意向によって立てられた政仁親王に対しても良仁親王と同様に冷淡な態度を取るようになった。
sen.e: Finally Emperor Go-Yozei agreed to this, however he treated Prince Kotohito coldly same way he did to Prince Katahito, it was not Emperor's intention but Ieyasu's to let Prince Kotohito succeed to the throne.

Finally, Emperor Go-Yozei agreed to this; however, he treated Prince Kotohito coldly the same way he had Prince Katahito, since it was not the Emperor's intention but Ieyasu's to let Prince Kotohito succeed to the throne.

Finally, Emperor Goyozei agreed to this; however, he treated Imperial Prince Kotohito coldly the same way he had Imperial Prince Katahito, since it was not the Emperor's intention but Ieyasu's to let Imperial Prince Kotohito succeed to the throne.

sen.j: 慶長16年3月27日に後陽成天皇から譲位され践祚。
sen.e: On March 27th, Keicho 16, after Emperor Go-Yozei abdicated, Emperor Go-Mizunoo succeeded to the throne.
On March 27, Keicho 16, after Emperor Go-Yozei abdicated, Emperor Go-Mizunoo succeeded to the throne.
On March 27, 1611, after Emperor Goyozei abdicated, Emperor Gomizunoo succeeded to the throne.
sen.cmt: 慶長16年を1611としました。Goyozei, Gomizunoo に修正しました。

sen.j: 4月12日に即位の礼を行う。
sen.e: There was an enthronement ceremony held on 12 April.
An enthronement ceremony was held on April 12.
An enthronement ceremony was held on April 12.

sen.j: だが、父・後陽成上皇との不仲はその後も続き、南光坊天海や板倉勝重の仲裁にも関わらず不仲は後陽成の死まで続いた。
sen.e: However the bitter relationship with his father, ex-Emperor Go-Yozei continued for a long time until his father died despite of Nanko-bo Tenka and Katsushige ITAKURA's help.
However, the bitter relationship with his father, ex-Emperor Go-Yozei, continued for a long time until his father died, despite the help of Nanko-bo Tenka and Katsushige ITAKURA.
However, the bitter relationship with his father, Retired Emperor Goyozei, continued for a long time despite the intermediary of Nankobo Tenkai and Katsushige ITAKURA until his father died.

sen.j: 江戸幕府は朝廷の行動の統制を目的として慶長18年6月16日（1613年8月2日）には、「公家衆法度」「勅許紫衣（しえ）法度」を制定し、次いで慶長20年7月17日（1615年9月9日）には「禁中並公家諸法度」を公布した。
sen.e: Edo Government issued Kuge shu hatto (the laws for Court nobles) and the laws that prohibit purple robes for high-rank priests that had been granted by an emperor on August 2nd, 1613 to rule Imperial Palace's act, followed by issuing the laws for the Court in the Edo period on July 17th, Keicho 20. (September 9th, 1615)

The Edo government issued Kuge shu hatto (the laws for court nobles) and the laws prohibiting purple robes for high-ranking priests that had been granted by the Emperor on August 2, 1613, to rule as an act of the Imperial Palace, followed by the issuance of laws for the court in the Edo period on July 17, Keicho 20 (September 9, 1615).

The Edo government issued Kuge shu hatto (the laws for court nobles) and Shie hatto (the laws prohibiting purple robes for high-ranking priests that had been granted by the Emperor) on August 2, 1613, to rule as an act of the Imperial Palace, followed by the issuance of Kinchu narabi ni kugesho hatto the (laws for the court in the Edo period) on September 9, 1615.
sen.cmt: Shie hatto, Kinchu narabi ni kugesho hatto 日本名を追加し、その後に括弧で英語訳を入れました。 西暦のみにしました。

sen.j: 以後、朝廷の行動全般が京都所司代を通じて幕府の管理下に置かれた上に、その運営も摂政・関白が朝議を主宰し、その決定を武家伝奏を通じて幕府の承諾を得る事によって初めて施行できる体制へと変化を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: After that all the action of Imperial Palace were under the control of the government through the shogunate's military governor stationed in Kyoto, the regent and the chancellor organized the Court Council and the running of the Palace was determined after receiving the approval from the government.

Subsequently, all the actions of the Imperial Palace were under the control of the government through the shogunate's military governor, who was stationed in Kyoto; meanwhile, the regent and chancellor organized the Court Council, and the running of the palace was determined after receiving approval from the government.

Subsequently, all the actions of the Imperial Palace were under the control of the government through Kyoto Shoshidai (the Kyoto deputy); meanwhile, the regent and chancellor organized the Court Council, and the running of the palace was determined after receiving approval from the government.
sen.cmt: 京都所司代 を追加しました。

sen.j: これによって摂家以外の公卿や太上天皇は朝廷の政策決定過程から排除され、幕府の方針に忠実な朝廷の運営が行われる事を目指していた。
sen.e: Due to this Court nobles excluding regent and chancellor families and ex-emperors were not involved in the final process of making political decision for the Imperial Palace, it was aimed to run the Palace in accordance with the government policy.

Consequently, court nobles (excluding the regent and chancellor families and ex-emperors) were not involved in the final process of making political decisions for the Imperial Palace; it was intended that the palace should be run in accordance with the government policy.

Consequently, court nobles (excluding the regent and chancellor families) and retired emperors were not involved in the final process of making political decisions for the Imperial Palace; it was intended that the palace should be run in accordance with the government policy.
sen.cmt: 括弧の場所を移動、retired emperorsとしました。

sen.j: 寵愛の女官四辻与津子との間に皇子・皇女が居た事が発覚すると、徳川秀忠は娘の徳川和子の入内を破談にすると恫喝するが、近臣を処罰するなどの詫びを行い、元和6年（1620年）に徳川和子が女御として入内する。
sen.e: When it was found out that there were Prince and Princess between Emperor Go-Mizunoo and his favorite court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI, Hidetada TOKUGAWA was furious and he said to cancel the arrangement to make her daughter the Imperial Consort's bridal entry into court, however some close aides were punished and Kazuko was arranged to become Consort in the Palace in 1620.

When it was found out that there were a prince and princess between Emperor Go-Mizunoo and his favorite court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI, a furious Hidetada TOKUGAWA demanded the cancellation of the arrangement [in order to?] to make her daughter the imperial consort's bridal entry into court; however, some close aides were punished, and in 1620 it was arranged that Kazuko would become a consort in the palace.

When it was found out that there were a prince and princess between Emperor Gomizunoo and his favorite court lady, Yotsuko YOTSUTSUJI, Hidetada TOKUGAWA was furious and he demanded the cancellation of the arrangement to make his daughter, Masako TOKUGAWA, become the Imperial consort; however, some close aides were punished, and in 1620 it was arranged that Masako would become a consort in the palace.

sen.j: 寛永4年（1627年）に紫衣事件、徳川家光の乳母である福（春日局）が無位無官で朝廷に参内するなど天皇の権威を失墜させる江戸幕府のおこないに耐えかねた天皇は同6年11月8日、二女の興子内親王（のちの明正天皇）に譲位した。
sen.e: In 1627 there was the Shie Incident happened, Fuku (Kasuga no tsubone), Iemitsu TOKUGAWA's educator, went to the Imperial Palace as a common citizen, the Emperor could not take the situation that he had to live with the humiliation from the government, he abdicated the throne on November 8th, 1627 and passed the position to his second daughter, Princess Okiko. (later called Emperor Meisho)

In 1627 the Shie Incident occurred, in which Fuku (Kasuga no tsubone), the educator of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, went to the Imperial Palace as a common citizen; however, the Emperor could not take the situation whereby he had to live with the humiliation from the government, so he abdicated the throne on November 8, 1627 and passed the position to his second daughter, Princess Okiko (later called Empress Meisho).

Because of the incidents such as Shie Incident of 1627, and another in which Fuku (Kasuga no tsubone), the wet nurse of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, went to the Imperial Palace as a common citizen, the Emperor could not take the situation whereby he had to live with the humiliation from the Edo government, so he abdicated the throne on November 8, 1627 and passed the position to his second daughter, Imperial Princess Okiko (later called Empress Meisho).
sen.cmt: 紫衣事件と春日局の事件を分けました。 Imperial Princessとしました。"educator"→"wet nurse"に変更しました。

sen.j: 一説には病気の天皇が治療のために灸を据えようとしたところ、「玉体に火傷の痕をつけるなどとんでもない」と廷臣が反対したために退位して治療を受けたと言われているが、天皇が灸治を受けた前例（高倉天皇・後宇多天皇両天皇）もあり、譲位のための口実であるとされている。
sen.e: There is one theory that the Emperor wished to be administered moxibustion, but his courtier was against it by saying 'It is out of the question that the Emperor has burned mark on the body', thus the Emperor decided to abdicate to have moxa cautery treatment done, however there was an example the former emperors had the same treatment done, (Emperor Takakura and Emperor Go-Uda) so it is presumed that was just an excuse to abdicate.

There is one theory that the Emperor wished to be administered moxibustion, but his courtier was against it, saying, 'It is out of the question that the Emperor has a burned mark on the body'; consequently, the Emperor decided to abdicate in order to have moxa cautery treatment done, but there was an example the former emperors had the same treatment done (Emperor Takakura and Emperor Go-Uda), so it is presumed to have been an excuse to abdicate.

There is one theory that the Emperor wished to be administered moxibustion, but his courtier was against it, saying, 'It is out of the question that the Emperor has a burned mark on the body'; consequently, the Emperor decided to abdicate in order to have moxa cautery treatment done, but there was an example the former emperors had the same treatment done (Emperor Takakura and Emperor Gouda), so it is presumed to have been an excuse to abdicate.

sen.j: 以後、霊元天皇までの4代の天皇の後見人として院政を行う。
sen.e: After that Emperor Go-Mizunoo continued his cloister government as a guardian four generations until Emperor Reigen's era.
Subsequently, Emperor Go-Mizunoo continued his cloister government as a guardian of four generations until the era of Emperor Reigen.
Subsequently, Emperor Gomizunoo continued his cloister government as a guardian of four generations until the era of Emperor Reigen.

sen.j: その後も上皇（後に法皇）と幕府との確執が続く。
sen.e: The conflict between ex-Emperor (later became a monk-Emperor) and the government continued.
The conflict between the ex-emperor (who later became a monk-emperor) and the government continued.
The conflict between the Retired Emperor (who later became a Cloistered Emperor) and the government continued.
sen.cmt: Retired Emperor, Cloistered Emperorとしました。

sen.j: また、東福門院（徳川和子）に対する配慮から後光明天皇・後西天皇・霊元の3天皇の生母（壬生院園光子・逢春門院櫛笥隆子・新広義門院園国子）に対する女院号贈呈が死の間際（壬生院の場合は後光明天皇崩御直後）に行われ、その父親（園基任・櫛笥隆致・園基音）への贈位贈官も極秘に行われるなど、幕府の朝廷に対する公然・非公然の圧力が続いたとも言われている。
sen.e: Also for the consideration towards Tofuku mon in (Kazuko TOKUGAWA), the birth mother of Emperor Go-Komyo, Emperor Gosai and Emperor Reigen,(Mibu in Mitsuko SONO), Hoshun mon in Takako KUSHIGE, Shin Kogi mon in Kuniko SONO) was presented Nyoin go just before she died, (it was before Emperor Go-Komyo died for Mibu in) and her father (Mototo SONO, 櫛笥隆致, Motone SONO) was given a special rank and position secretly, it is said the government kept on direct and indirect pressure to the Imperial Palace.

Also, in consideration of Tofuku mon in (Kazuko TOKUGAWA), the birth mother of Emperor Go-Komyo, Emperor Gosai and Emperor Reigen (Mibu-in Mitsuko SONO), Hoshun mon in Takako KUSHIGE, Shin Kogi mon-in Kuniko SONO), Nyoin go was presented just before she died (this was before Emperor Go-Komyo died for Mibu-in) and her father (Mototo SONO, 櫛笥隆致, Motone SONO) was secretly given a special rank and position; it is said that the government had maintained direct and indirect pressure upon the Imperial Palace.

Also, in consideration toward Tofukumonin (Masako TOKUGAWA), to the birth mothers of Emperor Gokomyo, Emperor Gosai and Emperor Reigen (Mibuin Mitsuko SONO, Hoshunmonin Takako KUSHIGE, Shinkogimonin Kuniko SONO), Nyoin go was presented just before they died (to Mibuin, Nyoin go was presented immediately after Emperor Gokomyo died) and their fathers (Mototo SONO, Takashi KUSHIGE, Motone SONO) were secretly given a special rank and position; it is said that the government maintained direct and indirect pressure upon the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: birth mothers（複数）としました。 女院号を与えられたのは、東福門院ではなく、3人の生母の死の直前、のようでしたので before they died としました。 女院号を与えられた生母の父親 と解釈し、their fathersと訳しました。 櫛笥隆致の読みを入れました。

sen.j: その一方で、本来は禁中外の存在である「院政の否定」を対朝廷の基本政策としてきた幕府が後水尾上皇（法皇）の院政を認めざるを得なかった背景には東福門院が夫の政治方針に理解を示し、その院政を擁護したからでもある。
sen.e: On the other hand, the government set as their basic policy to prevent 'ruling cloister government' which should have been naturally up to the Imperial Palace to control, however the government had no choice but to accept Emperor Go-Mizunoo's (a monk-emperor) cloister government, since Tofuku mon in understood her husbands intention to rule the cloister government and protected him from the political pressure.

However, the government had as its basic policy the prevention of a 'ruling cloister government,' which should logically have been up to the Imperial Palace to control; however, the government had no choice but to accept the cloister government of Emperor Go-Mizunoo, since Tofuku mon-in understood her husband's intention to rule the cloister government and protected him from the political pressure.

Moreover, the government had set a basic policy to prevent a 'ruling cloister government,' which should have been naturally up to the Imperial Palace to control; however, the government had no choice but to accept the cloister government of Retired (Cloistered) Emperor Gomizunoo, since Tofukumonin understood her husband's intention to rule the cloister government and protected him from the political pressure.
sen.cmt: However を Moreoverに変更しました（文のつながり上） Cloistered Emperorとしました。"(Cloistered) Emperor Gomizunoo"→"Retired (Cloistered) Emperor Gomizunoo"に変更しました。

sen.j: 延宝8年に85歳の長寿で崩御し、泉涌寺内の月輪陵（つきのわのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: In Enpo 8 the Emperor lived until eighty five years and died, he was entombed in Tsuki no wa no misasagi within Sen nyu-ji Temple.
The Emperor lived to the age of 85 and died in Enpo 8; he was entombed within Sen nyu-ji Temple in Tsuki no wa no misasagi.
The Emperor lived to the age of eighty-five and died in 1680; he was entombed within Sennyu-ji Temple in Tsukino Wa no Misasagi.
sen.cmt: 延宝8年を1680としました。数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 尚、京都市上京区の相国寺境内には後水尾天皇の毛髪や歯を納めた、後水尾天皇髪歯塚が現存する。
sen.e: There is a burial mound in the grounds of the Shokuku-ji Temple where Emperor Go-Mizunoo's hair and teeth are kept.
There is a burial mound on the grounds of the Shokuku-ji Temple, where Emperor Go-Mizunoo's hair and teeth are kept.
There is a burial mound on the grounds of the Shokoku-ji Temple, in Kamigyo Ward of Kyoto City, where Emperor Gomizunoo's hair and teeth are kept.
sen.cmt: 住所を追加しました。Gomizunoo としました。

sen.j: 1985年7月12日までは歴代最長寿の天皇でもあった。
sen.e: He lived to be the oldest of all the previous emperors until July 12, 1985.

sen.j: なお、後水尾天皇の記録を抜いた昭和天皇は、「後水尾天皇の時は平均寿命が短く、後水尾天皇の方が立派な記録です」とコメントしている。
sen.e: There is Emperor Showa who beat the long living record of Emperor Go-Mizunoo, he said, 'Since during Emperor Go-Mizunoo's reign, people lived shorter life, so his record is more valuable than mine.'
Said Emperor Showa, who beat the long-standing record of Emperor Go-Mizunoo, 'During Emperor Go-Mizunoo's reign, people's lives were shorter, so his record is more valuable than mine.'
Said Emperor Showa, who beat the long-standing record of Emperor Gomizunoo, 'During Emperor Gomizunoo's reign, people's lives were shorter, so his record is more valuable than mine.'

sen.j: 日光東照宮には陽明門をはじめ各所に後水尾天皇の御親筆とされる額が掲げられており、後に板垣退助が強硬に日光東照宮の焼き討ちを要求する薩摩藩を説得する理由の1つとして挙げたとされる。
sen.e: There are some Emperor Go-Mizunoo's flamed calligraphy displayed at Yomei-mon Gate or other area in Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine, it is said later on when the Satsuma clan demanded to burn the temple, Taisuke ITAGAKI persuaded them not to, one of the reason being having those historical materials inside, thus the temple was kept safe.

Some of Emperor Go-Mizunoo's flame-damaged calligraphy is displayed at Yomei-mon Gate or other areas in Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine, about which it is said that later, when the Satsuma clan demanded that the temple be burned, Taisuke ITAGAKI persuaded them not to, one of the reasons being that there were such historical materials inside, and therefore the temple was saved.

Some of Emperor Gomizunoo's framed calligraphy is displayed at Yomei-mon Gate or other areas in Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine, about which it is said that later, when the Satsuma clan demanded that the shrine be burned, Taisuke ITAGAKI persuaded them not to, one of the reasons being that there were such historical materials inside, and therefore the shrine was saved.
sen.cmt: flame→ frame temple →shrine としました。

Posthumous name, Tsuigo, a different name

sen.j: 遺諡により後水尾と追号された。
sen.e: The Emperor received posthumous name of Go-Mizunoo.

sen.e: The Emperor received the posthumous name of Go-Mizunoo.
The Emperor received the posthumous name of Gomizunoo.

sen.j: 水尾とは清和天皇の異称である。
sen.e: Mizunoo was the different name of Emperor Seiwa.
Mizunoo was a different name for Emperor Seiwa.
Mizunoo was a different name for Emperor Seiwa.

sen.j: 後水尾天皇は、不和であった父後陽成天皇に、乱行があるとして退位に追い込まれた陽成天皇の「陽成」の加後号を贈り、自らは陽成の父であった清和天皇の異称「水尾」の加後号を名乗るという意志を持っていたことになる。
sen.e: The Emperor had an intention to name Emperor Seiwa's Kago name (same name as the former emperor with 'go' added in the beginning) of the different name, 'Mizunoo', instead of taking Kago name from his father, Emperor Go-Yozei, since he was infamous for misconduct.
sen.cmt: 加後号→頭に『後』がつく追号[www.toride.com] 定訳不明
sen.e: The Emperor intended to take the name of Emperor Seiwa's Kago (the same name as the former emperor but with the prefix 'go') or the different name, 'Mizunoo,' instead of taking the Kago name from his father, Emperor Go-Yozei, since he was infamous for misconduct.

The Emperor intended to take the Kagogo (a kind of posthumous name) of Emperor Seiwa's different name, 'Mizunoo' (Emperor Seiwa was a father of Emperor Yozei) for himself, and instead presented to his father 'Yozei' as the Kagogo of the Emperor Goyozei (Emperor Yozei was infamous for misconduct and was forced to be abdicated).
sen.cmt: より原文どおりになるように修正しました 加後号を a kind of posthumous nameと補足しました。

sen.j: このような父子逆転の加後号は他に例がない。

There is no other example like the above, in which the son's and father's names have been turned around.
There is no other example like the above, in which the son's and father's names have been turned around.

sen.j: 遺諡は、鎌倉時代の後嵯峨天皇から南北朝時代・室町時代の後小松天皇にかけて多くあったが、その後7代にわたって絶えており、後水尾の遺諡は後小松以来約2世紀ぶりである。
sen.e: There are many examples of the posthumous name from Emperor Go-saga in the Kamakura period to Emperor Go-Kamatsu in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties, and Muromachi period, then it stopped for next seven generations, the posthumous of Go-Mizunoo was the first one since seven century after Emperor Go-Komatsu.

There are many examples of the posthumous name from Emperor Go-saga in the Kamakura period to Emperor Go-Kamatsu in the period of the Northern and Southern dynasties, as well as in the Muromachi period, after which it stopped for the next seven generations; the posthumous name of Go-Mizunoo was the first one since the seventh century, after Emperor Go-Komatsu.

There are many examples of the posthumous names from Emperor Gosaga in the Kamakura period to Emperor Gokomatsu in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, as well as in the Muromachi period, after which it stopped for next seven generations; the posthumous name of Gomizunoo was the first one after two centuries, after Emperor Gokomatsu.
sen.cmt: two centuries追加しました。名前を修正しました。

sen.j: このことからも後水尾の強い意志が伺われる。
